thread.title: After 'minor' ankle injury, Trail Blazers' Damian Lillard realizes 'I need to stay off floor'
thread.title_full: After 'minor' ankle injury, Trail Blazers' Damian Lillard realizes 'I need to stay off floor' | OregonLive.com

author: Jason Quick | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: After 'minor' ankle injury, Trail Blazers' Damian Lillard realizes 'I need to stay off floor'
text:
It was the one sight no Trail Blazers fan wanted to see Thursday: Damian Lillard limping off the court.
But there was the Blazers' star at the end of the third quarter, hobbling off the court with a wince because of a re-aggravated left ankle sprain.
Although Lillard called the injury "minor" it was enough of a scare to cause him to reverse his thinking about his play moving forward this preseason.
"I need to stay off the floor,'' Lillard conceded after Thursday's 118-101 exhibition victory over Golden State.
After the Blazers' exhibition opener against Sacramento on Monday, Lillard went hard to the floor at least five times, but said he wasn't worried about the toll the spills took on his body.
But when Lillard once again had several hard falls to the floor on Thursday, including the final fall when he re-sprained his ankle, he said he will think about limiting the wear-and-tear on his body before the regular season starts.
"(Tonight) a lot of it was part of the action, not me being reckless; there will be games like that,'' Lillard said. "But I do need to limit that.''
Lillard said limiting his hard falls has been a point of emphasis since his rookie season.
"I wear a lot of padding now ... I got a vest under my jersey, arm pad, thigh, tail, knees ... everything has been padded up,'' Lillard said. "My rookie year I didn't wear any. But when I started hitting the ground, I thought it would be a good idea to protect myself. Each year, I fall less. The coaches talk about staying off the court, and I try to do a lot better with that.''
It hasn't worked yet this preseason, as Lillard is crashing to the floor at a high rate. On Thursday, however, the risks came with some reward: Lillard attempted 17 free throws, making 15.
Coach Terry Stotts noted that one of Lillard's strengths is attacking, so he doesn't want to limit Lillard's effectiveness by worrying about his health.
"I like him being aggressive,'' Stotts said. "I think it's important that he plays his game. The fact that he got to the line 17 times is something we need. I wouldn't discourage him from being aggressive.''
Lillard said he turned his left ankle in Monday's game against Sacramento, then re-aggravated it Thursday when he was on a breakaway late in the third quarter.
"I was trying to pick up speed and change direction, and when I changed direction, somebody bumped me and I lost my balance,'' Lillard said. "You know how it is when you turn your ankle â€“ it's just a little bit painful at the moment.''
Lillard has never missed an NBA game, and is usually adamant about playing through injuries, but he said he would consider sitting out one of the Blazers' five remaining exhibition games.
"I would. I would. I've had bad ankle injuries and I've had little tweaks, and I've had ankle injuries where I feel it could linger on,'' Lillard said. "This one is like ... minor.''
